name: co-walker

attributes.attribute: sometimes described as Twin souls, freed with the approach of death, but they were also spoken of as Fairies disguised as the person who stood on the edge of the Otherworld
who would ultimately depart and not be seen again, although it is unclear whether the danger was considered to be to the deceased or the living

sources: Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: A figure in Irish and Scottish folklore was the co-walker. It was said that shortly before or after someone's death, an exact duplicate of that person could be spotted walking around. A person near death might be seen attending church, while a recently departed man might show up at his own funeral. Some described these duplicates as twin souls, released with death's approach. Others claimed that they were fairies, disguising themselves as the individual standing at the precipice between worlds. It was of utmost importance to never speak to these apparitions or fairies, as they would ultimately vanish and never reappear. However, the nature of the danger was not entirely clear - whether it posed a threat to the living or the deceased.
